TO: NABB BOARD OF DIRECTORS
Inquiry #1
11-17-54
From:
Frank E. Schooley
Re: Subscription Television
lo Should NAEB take a position on subscription television?
Should it file if and when the Commission requests comments?
If you are not familiar with the latest may I suggest you
read Page 31 of BROADCASTING magazine, dated November 150
I am making a similar request for opinion of the Engineering
Committee, of the Television Development Committee, and of our
legal counselo
cc: Skornia
I have no definite conviction. I feel that subscription television
will benefit the theater type of spectacular and the feature movie
programs more than any other. The only way an educational station
would profit would be in the case of an outstanding football game
or similar broadcast.
I do not believe that many folks will pay to get the school of the
air or credit course kind of program. Perhaps I do not understand
the public but that is my belief.
I see subscription television as favoring a minority group by
giving it a monopoly on a public owned facility. It is the old
clear channel situation over again. If that is true then perhaps
NAEB should intervene to protect the future of public education
by television. It would be on this basis alone that I would
consider intervention.
These two points of view will have to be weighed against each other
and the NAEB position determined by which is the stronger.
